definition: Wang Can (177-217), poet, generally regarded as the most brilliant of "the seven masters of Jian'an" 建安[Jian4 an1]
surname Wang
king or monarch/best or strongest of its type/grand/great
to rule/to reign over
beautiful/bright/splendid/smilingly
Cao Zhi (192-232), son of Cao Cao 曹操, noted poet and calligrapher
Xun Yu (163-212), brilliant strategist, advisor of Cao Cao in Three Kingdoms
Kong Rong (153-208), poet of the Three Kingdoms period
Shen Yue (441-513), writer and historian during Liang of Southern dynasties 南朝梁, compiler of History of Song of the Southern dynasties 宋書|宋书
Cheng Yu (141-220), advisor to General Cao Cao 曹操 during the Three Kingdoms era
Cao Pi (187-226), second son of Cao Cao 曹操, king then emperor of Cao Wei 曹魏 from 220, ruled as Emperor Wen 魏文帝, also a noted calligrapher
Cao Chong (196-208), son of Cao Cao 曹操[Cao2 Cao1]
Zhong Yao (151-230), minister of Cao Wei 曹魏[Cao2 Wei4] and noted calligrapher, said to have developed the regular script 楷書|楷书[kai3 shu1]
Lu Ji (261-303), Chinese writer and literary critic
Liu Biao (142-208), warlord
Lu Su or Lu Zijing 魯子敬|鲁子敬 (172-217), statesman, diplomat and strategist of Eastern Wu 東吳|东吴
Zuo Si (3rd century), Jin dynasty writer and poet
Jia Yi (200-168 BC), Chinese poet and statesman of the Western Han Dynasty

Cao Cao (155-220), famous statesman and general at the end of Han, noted poet and calligrapher, later warlord, founder and first king of Cao Wei 曹魏, father of Emperor Cao Pi 曹丕/the main villain of novel the Romance of Three Kingdoms 三國演義|三国演义
Zhou Yu or Chou Yü (175-210), famous general of the southern Wu kingdom and victor of the battle of Redcliff/in Romance of the Three Kingdoms, absolutely no match for Zhuge Liang
Sun Quan (reigned 222-252), southern warlord and king of state of Wu 吳|吴 in the Three Kingdoms period
